w:r.w:t: to the beach in this lesson. They will develop their vocabulary and also work on responding to simple questions requiring them to respond with some of their recent vocabulary words.
Students will also work on using articles like “a” and “the.”

This slide will always be the
-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: Today, we are going to
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word:
Circle entire beach scene saying: “This is
Visual cue: Show various pictures of the beach.
Depending on the student’s location find a beach near them to add a connection.
The student may list off different things they see at the beach such as the water, sand, sun etc. depending on the level.
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word:
Have student write play on a whiteboard or on the screen.
Visual Que: Show pictures of children playing at the beach.
TPR: Act like you are building with a bucket or throwing a beach ball.
Ask: “What do you do at the beach?”
Coach student to respond: “I play at the beach.”
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word:
“What do you do at the beach?”
Teach the word swim, the consonant blend
TPR: Modeling what swimming looks like. Show different strokes, or plug your nose.
Say and spell Swim: S-W-I-M: Swim
Visual cue: Show different people swimming, especially at the beach.
Ask student: “What do you do at the beach.”
If they have trouble with responding “I swim at the beach.” Then say the sentence first using TPR to point to yourself and then show swimming.
Extension: Ask student if they like to swim using thumbs up or thumbs down.
line from swim to the child swimming saying: “Swim”
Visual cue: Show a whiteboard to illustrate how to match by drawing a line.
Coach the student to say “Play and Swim” while drawing the lines.
Have student repeat “He/she is playing,” and “He/She is swimming.”
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word:
Make waves with arms to show water
Show bodies of water and even water in a glass to illustrate that it is the same thing.
Ask student: “Where is the water?” Shrugging shoulders and modeling looking for the water- point to pictures of water or circle the water on the screen.
Teach the student the following sentence:
Student writes missing letter from the words they have learned.
l a word with a missing letter-
choose a word that has been taught in previous lessons like: hello, tree etc.
to model how to complete the words.
Instruct the student to read the word after filling in the missing letter.
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word
cle beach while saying the word saying: “This is beach.”
rcle ball while saying the word saying: “This is ball.”
“What do you do with a beach ball?”
Underline each word in the sentence: “I play with a beach ball.”
have already learned the word ball in
and beach earlier in this lesson, so it should not be too difficult to teach the two words together.
Say and spell beach ball: B-E-A-C-
Visual cue: Show a real beach ball if you have one, or pictures of beach balls.
TPR: Act like you are throwing the beach ball through the screen to the student.
Have student isolate each by circling the word
Ask: What do you do with a beach ball?
TPR: Shrug shoulders to signal a question pointing at the student when saying you and then pointing at the beach ball.
Have the student respond by repeating: “I play with a beach ball.”
Underline each word in the sentence while saying the sentence. Then have the student underline each word.
Extension: Ask student if they like to play with beach balls?
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word: Beach
TPR: “What do you see?” By motioning toward you and see by putting your hand above your eyes.
gle ball asking “What do you see?”
Student responds: “I see a beach ball.” If the student misses “a” have them repeat the sentence stressing the word “a.”
Circle the group of three beach balls asking: “What do you see?”
Student responds: “I see three beach balls” or “I see beach balls.”
Stress the plural ending “s” to show that there are more than one.
Visual cue: Show students various balls or pictures of balls saying “a” for one and adding “s” for more than one.
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word:
Say and spell sun: S-U-N – Sun
Have student clap out the letters as they speak: S-U-N
Have student write sun on the screen.
TPR: Make a big circle with your arms saying: Sun
Visual cue: Show different pictures of the sun
Circle the sun asking “What is this?”
Underline each word in the sentence while saying: “This is the sun.” Have the student repeat after the teacher, stressing the word “the” as the article.
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word:
“Yes, it is sand.” “No, it is not sand.”
Say and spell sand: S-A-N-D: sand
Have students write sand on the screen or piece of paper.
Visual cue: Show non-examples of sand asking: “Is this sand?” Students responds by responding yes or no.
end to look around for the sand asking “Where is the sand?”
Student responds: “Sand is at the beach.”
Extension: Ask- Do you like to play in the sand?

should be fast since this activity was done in slide six. Use the word play or swim as a review.
Instruct the student to read the word after filling in the missing letter.
Student draws a line to match the words to the pictures.
Use a whiteboard to show the student how you want the student to match between columns.
Depending on the level of the student have them say the word, make their own short sentence with the word, or have them repeat after you.
Help student find the correct answer if they are not able to do it on their own.
Circle each image and ask questions. Either: “What is it?” or “What is he/she doing.”
